There are so many different places to work at OSU, and your experience will depend a lot on the team you work with. In my experience my supervisor did not have a lot of accountability regarding how they treated me. Luckily you can do homework on your potential supervisor before taking a position, and I would encourage others to do so. 
Generally there is a lot of unnecessary Department/College politics and feuding to muddle through.
Also, the hiring of F. King Alexander as president was a very questionable decision, and the people responsible for that decision are, as far as I am aware, generally still holding the reigns of the university. Pretty disheartening.

review_title: Small Town Thinking in Small Town
pros: You can start your career here.
cons: When you are located in a small town, non-diverse state, and can only hire locals because anybody in their right mind would never move here, you get the picture. Diversity, Equity and Inclusion is all but a workshop and a front. You cannot change generations of non-diverse thinking in a workshop. Management is utterly lost and confuse as to what their goals are and people are afraid to step out and challenge clueless supervisors because there are no other job opportunities in town; aka everybody afraid to lose their jobs. This university has rest on being the biggest institution in the state, and you get lackluster performance from people who have never been at a cutting edge workplace. Nobody outside of Oregon considers this school for their education or hiring their students. There are too many gatekeepers because nobody wants to lose their jobs, so collaboration is weak at best. People are promoted or given positions because they know somebody, instead of being qualify. Most people are friendly, but you will run into toxic co-workers because they cannot hire the best. Start your career here and move on.

review_title: One of the best ratios of opportunity to accessibility.
pros: Oregon state is a land grant research institution, as well as a sun, sea, and space grant institution. While these terms might sound archaic, in fact what it means is that Oregon State explicitly aims to couple R1 level research in fields ranging from computational biology to off shore wave energy conversion Oregon State is a host to many active large scale research efforts in diverse fields. The open door and hybrid remote learning policies of Oregon State meant that operations continued seamlessly throughout the pandemic.
cons: Oregon state is situated in a relatively sleepy rural town, Corvallis. Not without it's 5 blocks of charming downtown. The weather is completely indecisive, it can be cold cloudy and raining, then hot drain and sunny 15 minutes later. The air is definitely pacific, and you will also need to bear in mind that many Californians are moving to Oregon for its parks, oceanside cliffs, and industrial farming. Then there's also the fact of legalization in Oregon to deal with.....

review_title: Experiences differ greatly between different units
pros: Salaries are pretty competitive in relation to other Oregon universities;
cons:
Not a good culture in terms of inclusion and holding the full workforce accountable for toxic behaviors such as bullying, intimidation, and discrimination against various marginalized groups. When issues are brought up formally, they use "support and advocacy" units to shield leadership from addressing the problems and ultimately only serve as a theatrical process for accountability as no real actions are taken. 
Very decentralized organization that requires each unit to develop their own systems for teaching and engagement, which creates a lot of wasted effort, redundancy.

review_title: A toxic workplace with little or no self-review - zero hope for change
pros: Chance to have a helpful impact on learners across the world. There are times when staff is encouraged to explore new or interesting tech. A vast number of high-caliber, immensely capable people make up the low level work force (they're amazing).
cons:
The lower-level staff is a group of people who are, across various teams/units, exposed to an autocratic or authoritarian style of leadership at the very top that hardly ever actually values the contributions of its people, in spite of the fact the vast majority of the workforce are high-caliber, excellent people.

• the vibe as many see it is staff aren't treated like the professionals they are
• many say they don't feel like they're even treated as adults (mistrust is the norm)
• leadership mandates actions or changes that do not take into account the experience/expertise of those on whom the actions are imposed
• folks in leadership take credit for accomplishments for which they did no work
• unfair decision making processes occur regularly, without any accountability
• suggestions for change, when brought to top leadership, is routinely disparaged and ignored
• there is zero transparency as to how decisions were made that substantially affected the staff (often negatively, such as insufficient staffing levels or increased workload)

I found Ecampus to be one of the lousiest workplaces I have ever experienced. I was miserable and faced repeated indignities upon myself as a person and a skilled professional.

Thanks to the way the org. chart works, most positions are dead-end jobs, with no room for any substantial advancement.

Lastly, if you read the Values and Goals as they're advertised, they SOUND great. But they are only superficial lip service to what would normally be inspiring goals. Very very little actual follow through.

job_title: Student Computer Consultant in Corvallis, OR
pros: I've learned a lot of valuable skills for software development, improved my ability to direct my own work, written a lot more code than I would have on my own, and gained some quality on-the-job experience. My department is extremely laid-back, with a mostly hands-off and low pressure management style that allows me to work at my own pace on issues that interest me while focusing on schoolwork and personal activities.
cons: Unfortunately, the downside of the management style is that our project is not very well directed and has experienced chronic delays due to under-estimation, poor planning, and exclusive reliance on student workers to produce a complex software project. Project requirements shift constantly and unpredictably, and live mostly in the heads of users, management, and student workers. Any personal growth has been entirely self-improvement, without guidance from management in areas like design, planning, or documentation. It's also very frustrating to work on a project that is so poorly planned.

review_title: Great benefits, overall good work-life balance, transparency could improve
pros:
-Great medical benefits and if you are professional faculty, great vacation time
-Overall, people are not expected to check email/be available after working hours unless there is a pressing project/deadline
-Progressive university, so there has been a lot of training on diversity over the last few years
-Beautiful campus
-Great technology available
-Innovative
cons:
-Like any organization, there seems to be transparency issues when it comes to leadership decisions. Staff feel left in the dark that work under those decisions and it ends up feeling like you aren't sure what to trust.
-No readily available resource to confidentially report behavior that you are concerned about if you are dissatisfied. You have to dig to find this resource.
-Pay is fairly low, comparatively
-There doesn't seem to be too much attention or initiatives to encourage employee retention and satisfaction
-review process is all top-down; no 360 degree feedback
-dated policies on telecommuting, flexible working arrangements. Remote work not encouraged, which is prohibitive when parking is very expensive on campus, office spaces are cramped, and if you are a parent you end up spending more time picking/dropping off kids, parking and walking into a distracted work environment then having everything you need at home.

review_title: UHDS Food Services Student at McNary
pros:
This job helps with living expenses and it actually work perfectly around with school since we have been able to set our own schedules. The pay is minimum wage but it is such a great experience to gain work ethics and some useful skills for future employment.

Plus, the environment at McNary is really friendly and not very stressful. Most of the staffs are friendly including the chefs. Other UHDS cafeterias such as Arnold and West are much more expensive and the environment and space over there are much more stressful.
cons:
Permanent staffs, mostly concept leads, comes in and out a lot which create inconsistency for students, especially those who have been around for awhile. Temporary staffs are not kept even though some of them perform even better work than regular, long-time staffs there.

New manager does not help around a lot, and she also does not schedule logically.

review_title: Student Worker - University Housing and Dining Services
pros: Very convenient, works well with your class schedules, generally good work environment, on the job training, no experience required, marginal taxes.
cons:
Only paid once per month, paid at the end of the month with a pay period beginning and ending in the middle of each month
No rewards for loyalty(I have worked for 2+ years and no raises), generally treated as being completely disposable. If you get injured, they don't let you work until you have a doctor's note, which is bad if you rely on this job to pay for bills. My current manager is too busy, doesn't answer emails, is rarely in the cafe, and generally does not manage at all.

pros: This is one of the best possible jobs as a student because they work around your school schedule. My managers always emphasize that my classes come first, and they have never put me in a difficult situation where I had to choose whether to go to class or go to work.
cons: There are no performance evaluations to let you know how you are doing. There is no mention of a raise except for the beginning of the year when minimum wage is raised. Even if you work there for more than a year, there is no real opportunity to become a student manager or anything like that. There really aren't any incentives to keep students around.

job_title: Student Support Technician in Corvallis, OR
pros: Felt connected to the OSU community, met a ton of great people, my bosses were understanding and flexible with scheduling when it came to school, and learned a lot of applicable skills for life after college. I worked for the university for most of my college career because I enjoyed it. The group I worked with was a mix of students and full-time employees, and became like a second family.
cons: For the university in general: Some people have worked there forever, don't necessarily enjoy their jobs, and seem to just be waiting for retirement. Also, there was a lot of bureaucratic rules that have to be followed, which can wear you out.

review_title: Great academic environment, but salaries aren't great and the local area is polluted
pros: OSU has a great college campus, many interesting and friendly people, and offers a wide variety of learning opportunities. The campus is easily accessible on foot, on bike, or by car.
cons: Academic salaries aren't great unless you make into the upper ranks of professors or administrators. The local area suffers from bad air pollution, iffy water quality, no smog control, and is an allergy/mold epicenter. The local Indians named the valley in which OSU is located "The Valley of Sickness".

review_title: Review from Research Associate working with MBI
pros: OSU offers a highly creative atmosphere and the research groups generally allow associates to have a degree of freedom in their work.  The management also helps balance work and home life.
cons: OSU has been following the trend of contract research for private enterprise by University entities.  This makes research employment very unpredictable and volatile.  Also, academics are known for not being able to keep the business enterprises from unduly pressuring the researchers to perform above the scope of work.

pros:
Short commute, lots of nature. 

Flagship Engineering college, lots of educational opportunity.
cons:
Constant budget crunches, furlows, and hiring freezes. Football seems to be a bigger priority than education.

Drama prone academic administration -- fired department heads, local newspaper publishing letter to the editor, leading to fired deans.

Little opportunity for upward promotion -- faculty and administration seem retire on death's bed, so don't expect to progress anywhere quickly as most positions are treated as national searches.

Administrative functions seem poorly managed, and underinvested in.

pros: The environment (including coworkers and management) was absolutely excellent. Huge projects in the summer brought the IT departments together, and managers all understood that as student workers, my coworkers and I needed to keep a flexible schedule. We were allowed to get the work done in our own time, so long as it was done well and in reasonable time for the users.
cons: You're going to make just above poverty level as a student worker, but that's going to be the case as a student worker at nearly any university.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Corvallis, OR
pros:
Lots of transdisciplinary opportunities
Supportive advisor
Kelley Engineering Building is very nice, really great location
Lots of nearby activities
Low cost of living compared to some other schools near the coast in the PNW/West Coast
cons: The Oregon State University "brand" is less well known than some other major players in computer science such as Stanford or MIT. Funding sometimes comes last minute. Some of the computer science/engineering classes are really large and mix undergrads/grads even when this seems unfair to the undergrads and/or limiting to graduate students. Occasionally this is a pro, because the coursework takes less time leaving more time for research.

review_title: Great job, great department, great people
pros: What a great group of people!  The staff is flexible, caring and understand that a working mom / dad has a daily balancing act.  Also, this is a part time job so it's perfect for me!!
cons: Only one!!  Get me out of the dungeon, I mean basement of Kerr!!  It's dark and dreary down here!  It's tough to work in the basement because there is no natural light.  Lucky for me, I am only here part time so it has not affected me as much as it could.

review_title: Very good as a University training university lectures.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Departments do hire almost ready to graduate PhD's to teach some of the course work.  The job title is a University Graduate Teaching Assistant, but the work is really for lecturers, as they teach courses on a stand-alone basis.  There, people do develop multi-media, electronically enabled, and web-enabled teaching skills.  These are invaluable teaching experiences.
cons: Those who are in fact acting as lecturers only get a "Graduate Teaching Assistant" title, and there is no parking assigned to these instructors.

review_title: Oregon State University is thriving - great people, great benefits, great town.
pros: For my specific position, I have flexible schedule, autonomy, interesting problems to solve, cutting edge research  problems to be involved with, and am surrounded by very smart people.  Great benefits, including almost 5 weeks of vacation no matter how long you've worked here.  Health insurance fantastic.
cons: Salary lower than private industry.  Most of my software development work is solitary these days and I miss the developer team experience.  Willamette valley is overcast much of the year, spectacular otherwise.  Job satisfaction is most likely highly specific to position.  My boss expects me to do a lot of self management, which is most often liberating, but at times challenging.

review_title: Principle Investigators are above the law
job_title: Faculty Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Stimulating place to work if you are willing to put in long hours.  Flexible work schedule, average pay.
cons: As a research assistant your supervisor has complete control of your life.  If your supervisor can handle this level of power without being a tyrant, then it is a good place to work.  However, most cannot and become tyrants and demand one to work long hours without pay or running personal errands to keep one's job.  I was terminated from my first job at OSU (after six years) the day I filled out a worker's compensation form. Workplace safety is an afterthought

pros: Recycling is a great cause and the job that I do is very structured and straightforward. Working on campus allows me to interact with many people all over campus and spread the word about recycling.
cons: Communication is a common frustration that occurs. Since there are so many departments around campus that we are involved with, it is often difficult to get everyone to be on the same page as far as recycling practices, and scheduled pickups.

review_title: Great position for those looking to settle down
job_title: Faculty Research Assistant in Newport, OR
pros: Great benefits and time off. Ability to include personal research interests in position as long as it pertains to the job description. Some positions have lots of travel potential.
cons: The time off is great if you get around to using it, pressure to work is high in many departments. Hard to separate work and life. Lab managers are usually Ph.Ds too interested in their own research to make sure everyone below them is being taken care of, employee turnover has been a side effect.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Research can be interesting, if you are on a good project. Campus is nice and corvallis is a reasonable affordable place to live, although costs are increasing.
cons: Graduate research assistants are at the bottom of the food chain when it comes to university employees.  If the PI is not running an efficient and highly productive laboratory you may get stuck as a poorly compensated graduate student for much longer than you expected.  In the life sciences, the post graduate career outlook is quite poor and is getting worse (at least according to the NSF and personal experience).

job_title: Student Software Developer/Analyust in Corvallis, OR
pros:
CASS is a mentorship program for students with a background in software.

- Mentors really do care that you develop good skills
- Friendly work environment run by great people
- Pay is better than anywhere else on-campus
- Student recognition near the end of the year is fantastic
- Good hardware to work whith (although this could stand a bit of an upgrade)
- Work is challenging and rewarding
cons:
- Some administrative issues, typically with the College of EECS.  These are likely due to it being a relatively new organization now.
- Sometimes the work can get thin for a variety of reasons.

pros: Supportive academic advising community, upper-administration is looking to add more positions to lower advising loads in high-volume areas. Lots of professional development opportunities. Students are awesome. OSU is a great place to work!
cons: Corvallis, while close to towns like Eugene and Portland, is a small town. This is both a pro and a con. You have to leave town for a big city experience or to eat a decent restaurants. While salaries have improved over the past few years for professional faculty (non-teaching faculty), it is still somewhat low. Also, OSU is on the quarter system. The pace of work has some extreme highs and lows when trying to serve students during peak academic advising season.

review_title: Great place to work while in school!
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros:
Flexible schedule around class time 
Able to work on homework during downtime 
Great staff and faculty to work with (in my department) 
Easy to get to classes from work, and vice versa
cons:
Pay could be better (around Oregon minimum wage) 
Often working low number of hours each week (9 - 12 h on average. Would have preferred closer to 18 - 20 h per week) 
Monthly pay schedule makes it hard to plan for bills and expenses (like exorbitant tuition prices)

review_title: Working at BSG has allowed me to learn a lot about hardware testing and networking components.
job_title: Student Test Engineer in Corvallis, OR
pros: Working knowledge of hardware and network testing, great co-workers, understanding and supportive management, fun and laid-back atmosphere, encouraging environment for asking questions even though it can seem intimidating at first.
cons: Hard to know how well you're doing your job because there is a serious lack of feedback, just something like if you aren't fired, you're fine, and I need something more than that.

review_title: College of Business NOT Run Like a Business
pros: The work schedule is tremendous! After having worked in the private sector for many years, academia really does offer a unique form of flexibility. The college has invested heavily in a new $50M building.
cons: Commitment from senior management are not always honored and "contracts" are unfairly biased in the favor of the institutions. Run too much like a governmental organization despite the official line of separating OSU from OUS as being a move in the direction of innovation and creative approaches.

job_title: EH&S Professional I in Corvallis, OR
pros: The work is life is very independent.  OSU EH&S is in a period of program development and growth.  It is easy to find a niche within the university.  It is a great college and a positive environment to work.
cons: Pay is low.  There is not much room for advancement as a classified staff member.   You will be in a EH&S Pro your whole career.  Professors at the university do not hold EH&S policies in high regard.

pros: Great employees, kind boss and managers. Environment at work is laid back and relaxed and since it is an on campus job you are able to take a day off for a test or something like that.
cons: Very fast paced work environment, during lunch can be very hectic. This is a minimum wage job with few opportunities for advancement.

review_title: A very relaxed environment with not super awesome pay but itll pay rent and your bills while you are in school
job_title: Arnold Dining Hall Employee in Corvallis, OR
pros: great for social networking. if you are a bit introverted or are having a hard time meeting people, its a great place for that
cons: It is real exhausting to work a full day of school and then go work for 4-6 hours. It isnt super fun but it isnt the worst i suppose

pros: Beautiful, remote location. Decent pay grade for the work.
cons:
Monthly pay schedule - I didn't get paid for six weeks after traveling cross country to a remote site for work - they didn't tell me I wouldn't be paid for six weeks until I arrived.

Poor safety standards and terrible lines of communication. The field supervisor made dangerous decisions putting us field technicians at unnecessary risk. Communication with lab PIs was practically non-existent and there was no avenue for recourse.

review_title: Typical University in terms of Graduate School
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros:
-Great location; tons of outdoor opportunities
-Good LGBT awareness and acceptance by campus officials. No where is perfect, but they make a strong effort.
-The Graduate School, Campus Health, and Counselling/Psychology are all pretty great to work with.
cons: Individual colleges can be really backward, in terms of actually educating and graduating students (especially grad students). Many of them have really lost sight of the education mission, in an all-out effort to scramble for shrinking funding sources. Many of the best instructors are gone, in favor of research-only workhorses. This is good for the University's short-term research productivity, but really really bad for the grad student attrition rate.

review_title: Valuable skills for a college student to take to any future field of work
pros: Strong values and culture; pushes staff to self advocate, offer feedback constantly, and consistently seek improvement; director has remarkable vision and passion for mentoring staff to be better youth care providers
cons: Bombastic working atmosphere requires staff to put in long hours some days, ends up taking a toll on people; pay scale is less than other organizations at OSU, much less than the staff deserve

pros: They are an extremely professional organization that offers training and opportunities. They offer telephone assistance to any instructor and will provide onsite support when necessary.
cons: Some of the training sites can be a little challenging. Other than packed snow or ice, they expect the classes to be held in all weather conditions. This can be an issue during very hot weather when extra breaks are necessary

pros: Nice place in the summer.  Had a great relationship with the advisor and the team.
cons:
Rains mostly in the winter but not an issue for me.
Job is temporary until the grant lasts, but learned a lot of industry oriented skills. Postdoc positions are like students when  it comes to benefits and like faculty when it comes to fees. No 401k and dependent healthcare insurance premium was very expensive.

review_title: Flexible with student schedules; otherwise, no benefits at all for student workers
pros: I have loved working as a student worker at OSU for the last few years. My supervisors are really flexible with my schedule and ensure I get raises without my even asking.  I have worked here for four years, all throughout my undergraduate program.
cons: Student workers receive no benefits at all, aside from a flexible work schedule.  It's really dismaying, actually.  And the new EmpCenter reporting system really puts us at a disadvantage when it comes to trying to make up time because we are limited to 20-hours per week during the term.

review_title: Your Experience Depends on Where You Work
pros: Many resources available to you on campus; great co-workers; great insurance and benefits.
cons: Because each college operates independently, your experience will vary widely depending on which college you are employed by and which department within the college you are in. There are constantly a 'restructuring' happening, of either leadership or the team. Very high turnover rate, which means constant change, and lack of institutional knowledge.

job_title: TA and Administrative Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Most managers on the campus understand that your primary reason for being at Oregon State is to get an education and b/c of this, they are flexible with your schedule.
cons: The biggest con is that most jobs on campus pay peanuts and there isn't really a way to get a raise with the way the wage system works.  You could make more money off campus.

review_title: Working in the Academic Success Center was an excellent student employment opportunity
job_title: Academic Success Center Student Receptionist in Corvallis, OR
pros: Great group of people to work with! Everyone is so committed to helping students through a variety of programs.  Upbeat environment even in very busy times.  Great learning opportunity for student employees for clerical/admin and customer service skills.  Work schedule changed term to term based on class schedule.
cons: Working in an office with normal business hours with a schedule built around class schedules sometimes made for short shifts (sometimes only 1 hour at a time) making it difficult to make a lot of progress on larger projects during a shift.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: I obtained my M.S. degree in Structural Engineering at Oregon State, and was very happy with my education. The Civil Eng. department has many great professors, who take their teaching responsibilities seriously. The labs are also excellent. Compensation was fair.
cons: No negatives really. Sometimes the work load is extremely heavy, especially during the first year (when the course load is highest).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant (COAS) in Corvallis, OR
pros: Beautiful campus, and a great town.  OSU has some pockets of sanity and solid work ethic.  If you like sports, there are lots to watch.
cons: The upper management has no concept of how they fit in the broader world.  They continue to build dorms and classrooms while the rest of the world is going toward online education.  They rob researchers that bring in their own money to plug holes in the general budget.

pros: The campus is a beautiful place to work, the majority of the staff and employees are great to work with. Students are fun and challenging everyday. The job requires constant flexibility (pro and con). Higher education is constantly changing and growing offering a lot of educational growing experiences.
cons: Campus is difficult to get on and off, adds a lot of time to your commute. Many of the jobs require you wear many different hats, most jobs are the equivalent work of two or more people. Everyday is different, there is no way to expect what will happen in a day.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albany, OR
pros:
If your appointment is more than FTE .29, you will get graduate tuition waived along with mandatory fees such as incidental, building, and admission fees.
Comes with pacific source insurance with vision and dental care.
Most professors are open to discuss expectations and pay info before you accept the position.
My PI is very supportive throughout my time there.
cons: Your whole experience as a graduate student / research assistant is largely dependent on your PI. Do your research and know who’s your advisor really is before accepting the position. If something does not work out, consider switching the lab and project.

review_title: Great experience in lifeguard position at Dixon Recreation Center
pros: Leadership was great and the training before-hand was thorough. The scheduling made sense and was easy enough to get shifts covered. It gave me as a student a fabulous opportunity to work while being a full-time student. Staff and co-workers were all friendly and the group dynamic worked well together.
cons: Sometimes could be challenging to balance life, work and school. Planning for tests, study groups and homework while having a job (these comments go with any job while being a student).

review_title: Be prepared to make sacrifices for the Northwest lifestyle.
pros:
Good location for a.)Outdoor, cultural recreation..  b.)Safety (esp. children).  c.)Mild climate.  d.)Still a relatively low cost of living.  d.) Informal community lifestyle.
  The University faculty are extremely generous with providing permission to audit their courses, and other opportunities for learning & professional growth. 
  Excellent benefits package, including state retirement pension, for full-time research (nontenured) faculty.
cons:
Salaries for research faculty are often very substandard.  This is somewhat understandable, given the benefits package; but salaries have not caught up with recent increases in local living costs. As a result, many of us were financially strapped working there.  In saying salaries are  "often" substandard, I meant that they seem to be departmentally determined - a coulple of  departments provide standard salaries, others have sometimes much lower standards, by a factor of 2 in some cases.   This is puzzling since such salaries are provided by individual grants to principal investigators, and are not themselves department-wide.  It's almost as if the PIs in each department get together and "fix" non-teaching faculty salaries to reduce the chance of intra-departmental wage competition.
     I have had particularly bad experiences with collaborations with other faculty.  It has been altogether too common that poorly derived, often blatantly false, information and defective materials were provided  to myself and my coworkers by current collaborators or prior workers for similar projects.  This not only results in significant lost time, loss of morale, and mistrust. 
  Like all state universities, OSU is governed by a state board of political appointees and it suffers accordingly.  From an educational and research standpoint, d ecisions made at the uppermost levels have been arbitrary, and agreements - especially those involving pledges of resources - have been made in bad faith.  Systemic morale problems have been the inevitable result.  I'm told that this is common in universities, and I am sure that is true for the case of public universities.  Nevertheless, a common problem is still a problem.

review_title: Research assistant at Computer Science department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros:
- I have started my graduate program about 2 years ago. The faculties in the CS department are active and are getting noticeable grants (especially in AI).  
- There are a lot of amazing nature cites and hiking trails around town which are perfect for someone who is into it.
cons:
- In general, the faculties are not very well known in the field
- Corvallis is a small town. In case you are a big city type of person with a lot of night life going on, here might bot be the prefect place.

review_title: Be prepared to work like a Dog for little reward
job_title: Graduate Teaching/Research Fellow in Corvallis, OR
pros: Learned a tremendous amount and felt prepared for some good job in the work force, but not necessarily the one I was trained for :/.
cons: Was so poor had to get food stamps, was regularly lied to and abused by my adviser/employer, became very ill and ended up taking longer due to severe abdominal issue. Got little support or understanding. Worked very hard and though I did well, was treated badly and paid little.

pros: I worked as a Teaching Assistant for a few years and it was a wonderful experience. I solidified my skills in computer science by helping out younger students and gained wonderful contacts in the real world because my teachers would actually help me.
cons: Sometimes the amount of grading balanced with actual school work was a bit daunting. But a few nights with a lot of coffee is worth the amount of work I had to do.

review_title: It is really great to be at Oregon State University there is a lot of support.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Whenever I have needed to get help from anyone it was easy to find the answer I was looking for. It is a supportive, and competitive environment that allows me to thrive. There is ready access to resources for personal growth.
cons: Sometimes my work is so exciting I forget to do other things. There is not a lot of good Italian restaurants in town and I really like Italian food.

review_title: Hit and miss with the professors that you would be working for.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Full tuition remission, quarterly stipend, health, vision, and dental insurance. Own office. Working with the students directly was fantastic, especially when they actually came for office hours. Lots of opportunity to work on your own work while getting paid!
cons: Some of the professors were overly demanding and negative about students and the work that they would produce. God complexes existed with quite a few of the professors teaching undergraduate course work while viewing their non-groundbreaking work as the most novel concept ever.

review_title: Generally positive, no raises during 3 years there, but at least not laid off like many.
pros: They provide great benefits, and are flexible with hours.  In addition you can take classes for a reduced rate, which I did and they worked around my schedule.
cons: Budget cuts are cutting people always.  Also, due to budget cuts there are never really any raises, so no incentive to work hard.

review_title: A good place to get a graduate degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros:
Teachers and staff care about your education.
Strong industry connections for landing a position after school.
A decent amount of research funding.
cons:
General stress of graduate school.
Poor compensation for time worked with little benefits besides tuition remission.
Difficult to branch out into other areas of research.

job_title: Seed Lab Employee in Corvallis, OR
pros: Nice staff, easy work, air conditioning, great company-wide meetings, and interesting work (at first).  The seed lab is a good first job for students in college.
cons: Poor culture, inconsistent hours, poor management, lazy management, and lazy employees.  The seed lab is not a good place for people who desire any future in their career.  Step raises are the only raises you'll get, and promotions are far and few between.  In addition, there was a problem with sexist hiring practices.  I had to consistently do ALL of my boss' work because he was too lazy.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Government work is super rewarding. Oregon State University is a good government job. Also, it's located in Oregon which is a cool place to live.
cons: Government work is usually pays less than the analogous private sector job. That is certainly true for my position. It rains a lot in Oregon, which makes it hard to mountain bike.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Corvallis, OR
pros: During my time as a Masters student I was afforded a great deal of responsibility and I was able to grow my leadership skills
cons: There were not many cons to this position. I was paid a living wage stipend and had all of my tuition costs waived in exchange for the research I conducted on behalf of the university

review_title: Oregon State is a great place to work
pros: This is a very friendly environment that encourages creativity and experimentation.  The campus is beautiful and offers many wonderful opportunities to learn and grow professionally and personally.
cons: OSU struggles financially and lack of staffing puts a great deal of stress on people who work here.  Outdated processes also make change difficult.

review_title: A fine organization for a short soft-money research post in the College of Science.
pros: More-than-adequate lab space and resources, excellent people in Chemistry, CBEE departments, great flexibility in the position I had, adequate benefits, generally excellent student lab assistants.
cons: Student help is generally excellent but can be hit-or-miss.  Department politics can confound permanent staff, but not an issue for short-term researcher.  Retirement package weak and inaccessible to anyone with fewer than five years service.

review_title: good benefits, somewhat drama because working for state
job_title: Food Service Worker III in Corvallis, OR
pros: good benefits, job security after six months, can take summer off if want. trying new products and food, always got training.
cons: not guaranteed full-time during summer, although I was always able to maintain full-time. favorites from management is obvious, put under a magnifying glass like you are a child and no trust from some leads and management. It's hard to explain the dynamics but if anyone ever worked at a state position, I think you understand what I am trying to say.

pros: OSU is a large institution.   The employee experience can vary greatly depending on the particular people you are working most closely with.
cons: As with most large institutions you can easily find your self spinning your wheels in an unsatisfactory position unless you take assertive initiative.

review_title: My experience was very positive and I learned a lot.
pros: I enjoyed the free tuition, the comradery of my fellow TAs and the city of Corvallis. I would live here if it were possible.
cons: There is very little supervision of the teaching assistants, so if someone is doing a bad job, the department does not know about it, expect through evaluations that are taken very lightly.

review_title: Great opportunities, but need to be a hard worker
pros: My position was one of the most rewarding I've ever had. My co-workers were fun, and though some of the tasks were daunting at times, I made work fun. You take out what you put in... put in hard work and it'll be very rewarding.
cons: It is up to you to talk to higher management. If you don't take initiative for anything, nothing will get done. I'd recommend high-energy people.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Undergrad research at OSU can be a great start to your career. Remember it is EXTREMELY important to conduct research/internship in your area of study especially when you end up applying for full time jobs. It is also great to network with professionals in the academic sphere or gain references and, of course, EXPERIENCE.
cons: There is *almost* no opportunity for upward movement in research assistant jobs. It might seem like a dead-end job at times- just stick with it and graduate.

review_title: Not a good place for graduate students (biochemistry)
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Corvallis is a safe place to stay for 5 years. Few crimes, mild weather. Good for those who want to raise a family. PIs are generally quiet nice and less demanding than those at better graduate schools.
cons: Generally funding situation here is horrible. Some PIs don't even have a major grant like RO1. So no matter how hard you try, your productivity won't be very good. Most PhD students here majoring in biochemistry end up with one or two BBRC type of paper(s). Some of them didn't have any publications at all. In sum, this program is producing lab techs and forever-postdocs, not independent investigator as you would think.

review_title: A great opportunity, but working with some is very frustrating.
pros: Great place to start a consulting business.  Great flexibility with hours and time off.  Ability to run outside enterprises without issues.
cons: Working in the university system is very different from industry.  The saying that those who can go to industry and those who cant teach seems to be true for 90% of the people here.  Professors think they are super awesome but have no management skills.

pros: Working at Oregon State University's Engineering Helpdesk was awesome!  I had a great boss, great coworkers, and the hours were flexible.
cons: There were not many bad things about working at Oregon State's Engineering Helpdesk, only that sometimes you didn't get enough hours and that some of the hours were bad.

review_title: Great place for long-term workers in a relaxed atmosphere.
pros: Beautiful campus.  Lots of restaurants.  Great benefits.  Fair pay.  Training opportunities are always available.  Work flexibility is excellent if you have a busy life.
cons: Budget cut threats are common.  Union representation is required and the union is SEIU.  Lots of rain October through June.  Many employees get disgruntled because of management attitudes.

pros: Working on campus learning a lot of skills is why you go into this job
cons: The pay is horrible, starting at $12 an hour, even as a student  developer, is horrible. I'm not looking for much, but even $13/14 would be more doable. We have a hard time paying for rent and food on 20 hours a week at our wage.

pros: It was a great atmosphere on the campus.  Overall management seemed to care for the employees and the pay was what should be expected on a campus.  Overall, I really enjoyed working for OSU.  There were opportunities for advancement and management was understanding of a flexible schedule.
cons: The pay was what should be expected.  Sometimes there were communication breakdowns.  The exciting campus environment would occasionally beat out the balanced work environment.

pros: Great experience and interesting work, I was in an engineering lab as an undergrad assistant. Doing all sorts of industry related projects with companies all over Oregon.
cons: The pay is poor, but I guess these jobs are much more about the experience then the pay. Space is very limited and things get cluttered quickly.

pros: Great place to have a student job.  Online scheduling was very advanced and I learned a lot about media services.
cons: Favorites were picked when it came to making schedules and promoting people.  If you were the boss' nephew, you get promoted even though you cannot turn on and run the projector correctly.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: The tuition remission is amazing, and 1,700 dollars a month is almost just enough to eek out a meager life. Can't argue with the learning opportunities; however make sure you like your advisor!
cons: Did a lot of good work for low pay, its unfortunate considering how much money my research brought in for the school how little pay I received. Also taking classes, teaching and trying to do good research can be overwhelming.

pros: The office culture is great. Everyone is great and there is a lot of growth potential. Another benefit I might add is the flexibility. Being a student, it's sometimes hard to commit to certain number of hours a week so it's nice because they will work around your schedule.
cons: Working on football gamedays is somewhat of a con however, this was discussed prior to taking the position so it's not like it was a surprise.

pros: OSU in Student Affairs is a great work place for professionals of all levels. I really have not found a better place to do my job.
cons: Not really a con, it is what it is, but having to pay $500/year to park adjacent to a work location while others pay only $350 to park adjacent to theirs is unpleasant.

job_title: Faculty Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Autonomy and room to take the position where ever we want to grow.  My manager is amazing and supportive.
cons: Grant funding makes salaries extremely limited.  Also, the university takes a large amount of grant funding as overhead so if a professor is excited about landing a new grant for your position, don't get too excited $25k+ of that per year will go straight to OSU.

job_title: Senior Information Security Analyst in Corvallis, OR
pros: Laid back atmosphere  lazy actually
cons: Stifles process improvement and innovation

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros:
Good pay/hour compensation along with tuition remission.
Easy access to all on campus health care and fitness facilities.
Good heath care package.
cons: The work load as a teaching assistant along with classes for a first year graduate student is strenuous. although it's pretty reasonable after that.

job_title: Student Dining Lead in Iowa City, IA
pros: Being able to work in a welcoming environment where we are able to help our customers in any way we can so that we may meet any and all of their dietary needs.
cons: Only being able to work a maximum of 20 hours a week during the school semesters and that not always being

review_title: GRA at Oregon State University, Engineering School
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Good facility and staff. Smooth communication within lab mates and group members. Faculties are highly solid technically and willing to provide advisory support. Lab equipment is well organized and maintained.
cons: Pay is standard among universities no matter how much effort you put into your research. But this is understandable since this is research institute rather than company after all.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros:
It's a very beautiful campus.
There are great services that you can use them while you are a student such as gym, student health center, legal services, career services, and a great library
cons:
There are not many funding projects in all departments. 
It's a quarter base education system. You have to work on your heavy course assignments every day during each quarter which makes it too difficult to work while you are a student.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: Some professors are flexible and completely reasonable with their workloads, but you won't always have control over your teaching assignments.
cons: When you get a professor that relies on you for all of their homework and test grading, some get too distanced from the sheer volume of work they're assigning you, and it becomes an unreasonable task to complete the required grading in a timely manner.

pros: The best reason to work on campus is the flexibility with employers. They allow you to work around your schedule, and take time off for summer and vacations.
cons: Poor growth opportunities, no benefits, terrible management at most places, rarely receive raises, unfair treatment, nothing really positive aside from employer flexibility.

review_title: They care about your professional development
pros: Extremely friendly people in the university and in the town. They truly care about your professional development and well being.
cons: Not really diverse. Some racist acts around the university and town, but those have been minimal.

review_title: Fairly flexible, low paying, good benifits
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: As a TA your pay is low. However the benefits of a TA are pretty good. 100% tuition waiver, 85% of healthcare covered. Time commitment depends on the department. You are usually expected to do more work than your FTE pay grade though.
cons: Poor communication, poor upper mananagement

pros:
Very flexible schedule; easy to get extra hours or get shifts covered
Fun to help undergrads learn their materials
Lots of downtime to do homework or work on other personal tasks
Often times a tutor may relearn things they forgot while tutoring the students
cons:
Poor pay rate
Oregon State offers their tutors very limited resources to help students
No appointment necessary often times brings too many students in at the same time

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: As a graduate teaching assistant, the job itself was pretty flexible. The professors were great in working with you, what was expected, and the work was challenging and fun. The pay was great for the work required, and the benefits were great (insurance).
cons: No real cons. The only real con I'd suppose is that I couldn't stay here forever, but they need room for more graduate students.

pros: Decent pay and hours. Work load will highly depend on the class or instructor that you support. Weekly hours can range from 4 to 20 and are often great when midterms are occurring.
cons: Only about 700 dollars a month so you will mostly likely need additional financial support. Some GTA's will do less work than you and still get paid the same.

review_title: Graduate research Assistant at the public policy program
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR
pros: The director of this program is amazing, hardworking and always trying to engage with students, GTAs and or GRAs. He is very resourceful and provides good advice.
cons: Depending of the professor you are assigned sometimes the work is not well outlined.

job_title: Student Food Service Worker in Corvallis, OR
pros:
-Workers tend to have tremendous flexibility in scheduling
-The work itself is pretty easy to learn and master
-Fellow employees are generally quite enjoyable to work with
cons:
-The pay is minimum wage, never rises based on performance or seniority
-Promotional opportunities are nearly zero, only a handful of student training assistants as a minor promotion
-Position does not transfer well into a 'real' job, especially not one outside of food service

review_title: Aggressive learning environment, and student friendly.

cons: Many older buildings that could use significant upgrades.  Very conservative campus.  Expensive housing for those on a limited budget.  Insufficient parking locations near work sites.  Cost of parking is high.

job_title: Student Support Technician in Wilsonville, OR
pros: Lots of free time to do whatever you'd like basically. Heck, you can even play video games, and management doesn't really care.
cons: Management isn't really there at all. Also, they hands off until they think something is going wrong, and they come down hard

pros: Its part time hourly work with flexible hours. You can grade whenever you want, as long as you meet deadlines

review_title: This is really a good group that is worth to join in.

cons: Testing job is a little bit boring.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Corvallis, OR

The job depends greatly on your adviser and your research. That being said, I was blessed with a great adviser and great research. I enjoy my work and it doesn't get in the way of graduating. 

The main benefit is that your tuition is covered if you are a GRA or GTA.
cons: Can be difficult to get funding through summers.

pros:

Pay is not the best, but it is well worth the experience.
You go on all day assessments which can put a strain on planning.

review_title: Teaching Assistant is a great job for a full time student
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR

job_title: Student Teaching Assistant in Corvallis, OR

Maximum of 20 hours to work, paid. I haven't reached that limit yet since I TA'd a lab-heavy course rather than an assignment heavy course.

Another con: Many students don't take advantage of the opportunity to get my help or to ask questions, which is unfortunate.

review_title: CASS is an excellent place for a student developer

cons: You are a student and are paid student wages, but that is more than fair.

pros: We can work even without a U.S. citizenship. There is no issue in getting our paid check a month after the grading work is done.

review_title: Great place to work  but hit hard by the pandemic; morale affected

review_title: Good company in a small town

pros:

review_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant at Oregon State University

pros: The direct manager is really cool and understanding about school and work schedule

review_title: Good gig, if you don't want to go anywhere else

pros: The management team is absolutely wonderful. They're very helpful in developing your skills and connections. They put your career first. On top of that they allow flexible scheduling so you can manage your time more efficiently and be better suited for school as well.

pros: Work around schedule, understanding managers, easy to get time off, paid above minimum wage. I worked at Academic Success Center and it was a great job for me to really gain transferable skills.
